dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jeremy Corbyn praising Conservative MPs? That just seems completely counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jeremy Corbyn praising Conservative MPs? That just seems completely counterintuitive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? But he was specifically celebrating their efforts to facilitate a smooth Brexit deal and prevent further delays.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? But he was specifically celebrating their efforts to facilitate a smooth Brexit deal and prevent further delays.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson urged MPs to vote against Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and his pointless delay as he doubled down on his oft-repeated promise to leave the trading bloc by October 31 come what may.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But he's also dismissing the October 31 deadline as a pointless distraction—isn't that undermining his own position?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he's also dismissing the October thirty one deadline as a pointless distraction-isn't that undermining his own position?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson urged MPs to vote against Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and his pointless delay as he doubled down on his oft-repeated promise to leave the trading bloc by October 31 come what may.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, he's arguing that the EU is eager to embrace the UK's progressive vision, so he sees the deadline as artificial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, he's arguing that the E U is eager to embrace the U K's progressive vision, so he sees the deadline as artificial.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he claims the chances of a no-deal exit are vanishingly high? That feels like a huge overstatement given all the uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he claims the chances of a no-deal exit are vanishingly high? That feels like a huge overstatement given all the uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that the chances of a deal are rising because the EU can see that Britain wants a deal, adding that the bloc may be discouraged by rebel MPs' actions, accusing them of making further negotiations absolutely impossible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but he added that the EU is actively avoiding negotiations because they fear any deal would insult their own processes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but he added that the E U is actively avoiding negotiations because they fear any deal would insult their own processes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that the chances of a deal are rising because the EU can see that Britain wants a deal, adding that the bloc may be discouraged by rebel MPs' actions, accusing them of making further negotiations absolutely impossible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, calling for Boris Johnson's immediate resignation and an election—isn't that just adding to the chaos?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, calling for Boris Johnson's immediate resignation and an election-isn't that just adding to the chaos?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He held an emergency meeting Monday afternoon celebrating Johnson's imminent resignation, so he seems pretty confident.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He held an emergency meeting Monday afternoon celebrating Johnson's imminent resignation, so he seems pretty confident.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson held an emergency cabinet meeting on Monday afternoon amid rumors the prime minister would call for a snap election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's reports he's offering Tory MPs key positions? That sounds like political maneuvering, not principle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's reports he's offering Tory MPs key positions? That sounds like political maneuvering, not principle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but opposition MPs are proposing an immediate Brexit deal—maybe he's this as a way to break the deadlock.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but opposition MPs are proposing an immediate Brexit deal-maybe he's this as a way to break the deadlock.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opposition MPs are reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit delay if Johnson does not strike a deal at the European Council, a summit of EU leaders, on October 19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: With protesters chanting "yes to the coup" outside Downing Street, it's hard to see this as unifying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With protesters chanting yes to the coup outside Downing Street, it's hard to see this as unifying.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Protesters could be heard chanting stop the coup outside Downing Street as Johnson delivered his speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though his supporters called it entirely constitutional and democratic—hundreds rallied across UK cities over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though his supporters called it entirely constitutional and democratic-hundreds rallied across U K cities over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thousands turned out across cities in the U.K. over the weekend to rally against the suspension of Parliament which was branded unconstitutional and undemocratic by Johnson's opponents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And if an election happens, it'd be the first in ten years after 2015 and 2017—that's a lot of instability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if an election happens, it'd be the first in ten years after twenty fifteen and twenty seventeen-that's a lot of instability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If an election is called this year, it would be the third in five years in the U.K., following votes in 2015 and 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, but Corbyn seems convinced an immediate vote is the only way forward now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, but Corbyn seems convinced an immediate vote is the only way forward now.

artist_script:
HostA: Jeremy Corbyn praising Conservative MPs? That just seems completely counterintuitive.
HostB: I know, right? But he was specifically celebrating their efforts to facilitate a smooth Brexit deal and prevent further delays.
HostA: But he’s also dismissing the October 31 deadline as a pointless distraction—isn’t that undermining his own position?
HostB: Well, he’s arguing that the EU is eager to embrace the UK’s progressive vision, so he sees the deadline as artificial.
HostA: And he claims the chances of a no-deal exit are vanishingly high? That feels like a huge overstatement given all the uncertainty.
HostB: Yeah, but he added that the EU is actively avoiding negotiations because they fear any deal would insult their own processes.
HostA: Still, calling for Boris Johnson’s immediate resignation and an election—isn’t that just adding to the chaos?
HostB: He held an emergency meeting Monday afternoon celebrating Johnson’s imminent resignation, so he seems pretty confident.
HostA: And then there’s reports he’s offering Tory MPs key positions? That sounds like political maneuvering, not principle.
HostB: True, but opposition MPs are proposing an immediate Brexit deal—maybe he’s this as a way to break the deadlock.
HostA: With protesters chanting “yes to the coup” outside Downing Street, it’s hard to see this as unifying.
HostB: Though his supporters called it entirely constitutional and democratic—hundreds rallied across UK cities over the weekend.
HostA: And if an election happens, it’d be the first in ten years after 2015 and 2017—that’s a lot of instability.
HostB: For sure, but Corbyn seems convinced an immediate vote is the only way forward now.
